Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: From Gabbros to Granites - An Investigation of Arc-Scale Differentiation at the Guadalupe Igneous Complex, Sierra Nevada, CA
Award.AbstractNarration:
Just a few key features allow Earth to be easily recognized from its planetary neighbors: water, continental crust (made of granitic rocks) and plate tectonics. These features are likely interlinked, and appear to be essential for the evolution of a planet that can support human life. This study focuses on the origin and emplacement of granitic rocks, which form the stable continental crust, without which terrestrial life could not have evolved. The origin of granite has been the source of much debate for more than a century, as successive hypotheses survive, are modified, or abandoned in the face of new observations. They weigh in on the debate by examining two currently popular models for the evolution of the Sierra Nevada Batholith in California, which is home not only to the crown jewels of the National Park System (Yosemite, Sequoia and Kings Canyon), but which has long served geologists as a type example of how granitic crust is formed in the plate tectonic setting known as a 'subduction zone'. Subduction zones are regions of Earth's surface where one tectonic plate sinks beneath another, in the process generating both earthquakes and volcanoes. These tectonic regions are also referred to as 'arcs', for the arcuate patterns of volcanoes that such a setting develops, such as the Japanese, Aleutian or Marianas Islands. It is in these regions that granites are thought to form. When such arcs develop granitic rocks, which are buoyant and difficult to subduct beneath another tectonic plate, these eventually amalgamate to form the continents as seen today.

In this project, the team will investigate the two key means by which granitic rocks of the Sierra Nevada Batholith, California are thought to be created: crystallization differentiation, and partial melting of pre-existing lower and upper crust. Recent work has suggested that earlier-formed crust, which consists mostly of basalt and overlying sediments, is heated by the intrusion of more newly-formed basaltic melts, and partially melted to form granitic melts directly. These granitic melts then rise through existing crustal materials to accumulate at shallow depths. An alternative hypothesis is that newly formed basalts are transported to the upper crust directly, and there differentiate to form the granitic materials that now dominate the landscape of the Sierra Nevada. The contrasts between these two hypotheses are significant. In the first case, little new crust is being created during Late Mesozoic time?older crust is simply being recycled and remobilized. The age of the crust then is then older than the age of the youngest granites in this model. In contrast, when newly formed basaltic melts differentiate directly to form granite, then this represents a new addition of granite to the crust. There is no better place to test these models than at the Guadalupe Igneous Complex (GIC) of the western Sierra Nevada. This Jurassic-age pluton (~151 Ma) contains very rare exposures of the newly-formed basaltic melts that intruded the crust at the time that the GIC granites formed: our goal is to test whether such melts primarily caused heating and partial melting of pre-existing crustal materials, or whether they differentiated directly to form granite. Another advantage to our study of the GIC is that the rocks in this region provide an unusual glimpse into the crust into which the newly formed basalts were intruded. Unlike other granitic plutons of the Sierra Nevada, they can test whether pre-existing crustal materials provide an appropriate source material for the formation of granitic rocks within the GIC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were: (a) to evaluate if granitic rocks could form by in-situ fractionation of mafic gabbros (likely parental melts) in the Guadalupe Igneous Complex (GIC), a now solidified shallow level magma chamber in the Sierra Nevada, CA; (b) to use modern single mineral geochronology to constrain the timescales of magma chamber construction and in-situ fractionation of the GIC; (c) to evaluate if this “gabbro to granite process” could potentially explain formation of widespread granodiorite plutons in many arcs; and (d) to improve our understanding of the temporal evolution of magmatic systems in the Mesozoic (~250 to 65 m.y.) Western Metamorphic Belt, where the GIC is located.

We obtained for the GIC over 450 XRF whole rock analyses, over 10 isotopic analyses (eNd, Sri, and Pb), whole rock trace element data, and single mineral compositions from over 100 minerals including pyroxene, amphibole, biotite, feldspar and rare titanite. This included zircon trace element data and single zircon, ID-TIMS-TEA analyses from every unit of the GIC to determine high precision zircon ages and linked geochemical data.  We also examined thin sections and analyzed whole rock geochemistry from ~35 samples of volcanic and plutonic units in the Western Metamorphic Belt (WMB) surrounding the GIC. Whole rock isotopic analyses (eNd, Sri, Pb) were obtained from 10 WMB samples.

Results from these analyses indicate the following: (a) an-situ fractionation model, in which crystal-melt separation in the upper part of the gabbros lead to the formation of high-silica melts that fed the upper granites, is consistent with our data.  Thus differentiation occurred in an active shallow (≤ ~2 kbar) magma chamber; (b) that interstitial, evolved granite melt was segregated by volatile-aided, filter pressing after ~ 50-60% crystallization of the minerals pyroxene, Fe-Ti oxides and plagioclase from an intermediate (~60 wt. SiO2) ‘parental melt’; (c) that age and slight geochemical differences between zircons in the lower and upper parts of the GIC are resolvable. And that the relatively simple zircon textures and distinctive zircon trace elements compositions for each GIC unit point to a small amount of mixing between different fractionated units during pluton construction; (d) that mixing of the gabbros and granites seen in this pluton could produce the magmas needed to form granodiorite plutons preserved elsewhere in the Sierra Nevada; and (e) that the volcanic and plutonic rocks in the Western Metamorphic Belt are spatially, temporally, and geochemically linked. Volcanic rocks are roughly bimodal in composition, similar to the GIC, with the volumetrically largest composition being basaltic andesite. Plutonic rocks are calcic-calc-alkaline in composition and show a wide range in silica contents, differing from the crude bimodality of the volcanic rocks. These data also allow us to better understand how arcs evolve through time since they provide new data from the outboard (oceanic) Triassic and Jurassic magmatic flare-ups.  

Our conclusions above have the following broader implications: (1) they provide a direct example of the rates and processes by which granite magmas can form by fractionation of gabbros; (2) they provide evidence that shallow magma chambers existed and through both fractionation and mixing can result in compositional diversity of preserved plutonic rocks; (3) the GIC provides a dramatic contrast to the highly mixed, intermediate (granodiorite) plutons seen elsewhere in the Sierra Nevada arc; and (4)  that the Triassic and Jurassic arc magmatic flare-ups in the “outboard” or oceanic domain of the Mesozoic Sierran arc system had linked volcanic and plutonic systems both of which were fairly distinct from the Cretaceous magmatic flare-up.
